Literature Review: Environmental linguistics is an emerging field that recognizes the intricate relationship between cultural and ecological diversity. This field of study documents linguistic structures and verbal practices that enable speakers to conceptualize, encode, and transmit knowledge about the natural world. By positioning language as the preeminent conceptual framework and channel for environmental knowledge, environmental linguistics surpasses the largely metaphorical and narrative program of ecolinguistics. As Indigenous experts emphasize, natural phenomena cannot be understood apart from the languages that encode them, and vice versa. This understanding highlights the significance of language diversity in safeguarding biodiversity and promoting a balanced human relationship with nature. Environmental linguistics also contributes to the decolonization of linguistics by prioritizing knowledge coproduction over data extraction. This approach acknowledges the importance of Indigenous knowledge systems and promotes a more inclusive and equitable understanding of environmental knowledge. Research in environmental linguistics has focused on various domains of knowledge, including landscapes, lifeforms, time, sound, memory, and survival. For example, studies on the linguistic representation of landscapes have shown that different languages have distinct ways of conceptualizing and describing natural environments. Similarly, research on the linguistic representation of lifeforms has highlighted the importance of language in shaping our understanding of the natural world. Time, sound, memory, and survival are also critical domains of knowledge that have been studied in the context of environmental linguistics. For instance, studies on the linguistic representation of time have shown that different languages have distinct ways of conceptualizing and describing temporal relationships. Similarly, research on the linguistic representation of sound has highlighted the importance of language in shaping our understanding of the natural world. Environmental linguistics has also been applied in various contexts, including conservation and environmental policy-making. For example, studies have shown that linguistic diversity is a key factor in the effective conservation of biodiversity. Similarly, research has highlighted the importance of language in environmental policy-making, particularly in the context of Indigenous communities. By prioritizing knowledge coproduction and recognizing the importance of language diversity, environmental linguistics has the potential to promote more inclusive and equitable environmental policies. In conclusion, environmental linguistics is an emerging field that recognizes the intricate relationship between cultural and ecological diversity. By positioning language as the preeminent conceptual framework and channel for environmental knowledge, environmental linguistics has the potential to promote a more balanced human relationship with nature. This field of study has made significant contributions to our understanding of environmental knowledge and has highlighted the importance of language diversity in safeguarding biodiversity. As we move forward, it is essential to continue to prioritize knowledge coproduction and recognize the importance of Indigenous knowledge systems in promoting a more inclusive and equitable understanding of environmental knowledge.
